content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Definitely towards the hard side but it is fun and I enjoyed it a lot

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Probably too hard for a clash, but I like it.
Seems nice but i feel like it is pretty difficult for beginners.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: seems good now

yeah quite easy problem. In perl it's just:

$_=`sed 1d`;$"while s/^( *)([^
 {].*(?<!{))((
\1 +[^
 ].*)+)(
|\Z)(?!\1})/$1$2 {$3
$1}
/gm;print

done

Nice contribution!
The problem is fun and the difficulty is just fine for a clash.

idea is nice, I was thinking about Ruby or Python -> C++ transpiller pazzle, but I think it's not good for CoC because it's printing problem with complications, and you have to be sure each language with reasonable defaults "not fail" validators

In short it's probably good idea to make it more complicated and move to puzzles than try to keep it in CoC IMHO

I will of course be adding more test cases before making the contribution final but I wanted to get some feedback first. (edit: the test cases have been added!)

Is the difficulty level good? If it needs to be harder I could remove the constraint "The test cases will not include cases where you would need to insert multiple consecutive closing braces on different indentation levels".

Nice puzzle, I enjoy this one a lot! I think the difficulty is appropriate for a CoC. 

For a classic puzzle, one could for sure add the consecutive closing braces and/or adding indentation based on if, else, while etc. keywords (Could be extended to smth like a code beautifier/deminifier). But this could be much fun as a CoC as is.

honestly average CoCer will die
... and the last validator... killed me...

plz just add the last validator (with 1 char strings) to tests, it's really mean to have it only in validators

My thoughts:

I would accept this contribution if and only if tests are STRONG (add 2-3 tests plz, hope it's not really hard). 
I mean for any "honest" solution 100% on tests should mean 100% validators, no tricks, no hidden cases, no tricky chars (in this case it would be tabs or even spaces at the end of the line, IRL it's not the problem anyway, 1 extra regex)

No regex solution seems easy, but different languages can fall on attempts with stack and counting spaces, idk an example right now, but I feel like I would fail in some languages.

For regex it should be easy, just hard to test and rely on edge cases like (\n|\Z) end of like or end of file. In perl it works without \Z, but other engines? Idk. Probably JS won't like it.

The last validator is just the last test case with \S.* replaced with x so I thought it would be equivalent. I'll change that one and add a new visible test with 1 character lines. What other tests are missing?

way better right now: I like you added Fibonacci indentation test, because it's not obvious that indentation could be different in the same test (I mean from the description)

Seems like I've found an issue: my Perl solution fails on test 7 but visually produces the same output (seems like you have an empty line in a test and I need to chomp the result), but all other tests and validators are ok

just in case: if instead of "print" I do "chomp;print" it works, I know Perl is strange, but in a way, if Perl works it covers some old languages with PCRE as well, I mean in your case Ruby seems like does all dirty job just because of smart puts (actually it's also double-edge)


BTW I didn't test the number of lines vs. actual number of lines in test, probably it's a good idea to add some asserts into solution, I guess anyone who can read contribution doesn't care about the "real" solution, since CG checks author's solution to put contribution, asserts would be nice

replace line 6 in your solution with

code = $<.map &:chomp 

Usually, nobody cares, but here it's important I guess:
exit if code.size != n
Good call, that actually caught an extra newline at the end of one of the tests. I kind of assumed CG would strip trailing whitespace from the input, but it seems that's not the case!
